title: Modal causing double scroll Bar
content: In the end I found that the best solution was to toggle a class on the body when the modal is opened, this class would add overflow-y: hidden. This allows me to scroll the content of the modal if it overflows the body, but doesn't allow scrolling of the body itself at the same time. No more double scroll bars.

title: Does an index/documentation of all compiled POSIX functions exist?
content: Background: I'm writing some piece of platform-independent C# code, which sometimes has to access platform-specific native code using P/Invoke. E.g. I may have to access DeviceIoControl on Windows, or ioctl on POSIX-compatible platforms.

title: Can Syntax Errors be handled?
content: A syntax error means that the code featuring said error cannot be parsed. It doesn't even begin to be a valid program, hence it cannot be executed. Therefore SyntaxError exceptions are raised before the program is run, and hence can't be caught from within the program.

title: BOOTSTRAP Navigation Bar Doesn't Collapse at the Correct Window Size
content: So I have created a bootstrap responsive navigation bar which moves all links into a separate tab once the window gets too small. To make the navbar look better, I set white-space: nowrap; hoping that instead of allowing the links to go on to new lines before collapsing the navigation bar, the Navigation bar would instead collapse at the point the links went beyond the page border. However, this wasn't the case and the navigation bar collapses after the 2 rightmost links disappear beyond the page border.

title: JavaScript event that fires when all of the certain elements get display: none
content: So, say, I have 5 html elements that are hidden via class that has a display:none property. Then there's a button which removes that class on one of these elements with every click (5 clicks results into all 5 elements being visible). And then all of these 5 elements have "their own button" that adds back this class with display:none when clicked.

title: Does php evaluate the second argument of an or statement if the first evaluates to false?
content: So my question is about the behaviour of php in the case of an or statement taking two functions. When the first function already evaluates to true, is there a chance that the second function will still be executed?

title: Why is a promise resolved before a setTimeout
content: The Promise .then() callback will be invoked immediately after the code block completes. The timer will get a default minimum time of around 15 or 16 milliseconds, so it's definitely going to happen after that.

title: Why is a promise resolved before a setTimeout
content: The Promise .then() callback will be invoked immediately after the code block completes. The timer will get a default minimum time of around 15 or 16 milliseconds, so it's definitely going to happen after that.
